VARNEY: 3.2 percent growth in the first quarter of the year, what's Joe Biden going to say? What's the first thing out of his mouth when someone says, "Hey, three percent growth in the first quarter of the year, wasn't supposed to be like this. Is it still going to go for taxing increases? Is it still going to go for more red tape? What about Bernie? It's so unfair that we have to change the whole system, move away from capitalism, and go to socialism when you got three percent growth in the first quarter of the year? Come on.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: This is just a prize that's landed in President Trump's lap. And he created this, make no mistake.

BARTIROMO: Well, he's god deregulation. He did tax reform we know these kinds of policies work, Stuart.

VARNEY: Yes. And he's pro-business.

BARTIROMO: You had four percent growth in the second quarter last year. You got 3-1/4 percent growth this corner.

VARNEY: Right.

BARTIROMO: Give me a break.

VARNEY: And you were --

BARTIROMO: Where's this recession that everybody's going nuts about?

VARNEY: You were talking about these capex, capital investment.

BARTIROMO: Big.

VARNEY: I mean in software eight percent, was it?

BARTIROMO: 8.6 percent, Stu.

VARNEY: Put the word out, Maria.

BARTIROMO: There you go.

VARNEY: This is prosperity.

BARTIROMO: Hey, I'm saying the today, Stu, that's for sure.

VARNEY: Love it. We'll see you in 10 times.

BARTIROMO: You will.

VARNEY: "VARNEY & CO." top begins top of the hour 9:00 Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA, but we are looking at some pain at the pump, we're taking you live to California gasoline. I mean are looking at, some pain at pump live. We're taking you live to California gasoline prices soaring. Two historic highs, you don't want that to cut into economic growth. We're all over it, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We had great GDP numbers out today, up 3.2 percent. But gasoline prices are up across the country. They are skyrocketing in California. Robert Gray is at a Chevron station in Los Angeles this morning with more on that. Robert, good morning to you.

ROBERT GRAY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. Well, if you drive higher gasoline prices at the pump, may not be breaking news, but what is as (INAUDIBLE) take a quick move. We literally just saw them raising the prices here at this station, not just a little bit, up 20 cents a gallon, and that's $3.00 for a typical fill up of your tank there, extra you're paying. Take a look at the prices nationally. Gasoline price is spiking to the highest since Halloween, almost three bucks a gallon here in California, even higher topping four bucks a gallon.

We have to go to august of 2014 to see how high it's -- though the highest hits then. It was then one, of course, taxes of the about a dollar a gallon here, extra in California. Governor Gavin Newsom just this week calling for an investigation to what he is suggesting maybe inappropriate industry practices, and the industry, and refinery shutting down for maintenance or other issues.

Now keep in mind, prices typically are jumping this time of year as we start ramping into Memorial Day, but that's still a month away and they'll have to stay higher given higher and experts say the jump is going to go even higher.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DOUG SHUPE, SPOKESPERSON, AAA: Of course we're used to paying higher prices being here in California. And on the West Coast. But the double- digit increases that we've seen over the last couple of weeks have really given a lot of drivers a sense of sticker shock.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GRAY: Yes, Maria. We're getting close to five bucks a gallon here for the most expensive gasoline. That is sticker shock even for those of us who live here.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GRAY: Back to you.

BARTIROMO: I think California lawmakers really need to take a look at what happened when the federal government cut taxes, and how it moved the needle on economic growth. We'll be watching that story, Robert. Thank you. Robert Gray this morning in L.A. Still ahead, the border crisis. I'm headed to the U.S.-Mexico border this weekend where I will be live for a special edition of "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES." Join me live Sunday morning at 10 a.m. Eastern as I walk the border, and take a look at the activity in terms of apprehensions. We're talking about a million apprehensions this year, crossing into the United States, 70 percent of those people coming from Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador. We're back in two minutes' time. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It's a big week next week. Be sure to join us on Monday for my exclusive interview with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. He will be here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA 6:00 a.m. on Monday. We will have a special edition of "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" this weekend as well. I'll be live at the U.S. border with Mexico. Join me live from the border on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" at 10:00 a.m. Eastern over on the FOX News Channel.

Big number on GDP, guys.

BREWER: Impressive.

BEVAN: Yes. It's a --

BARTIROMO: They're going to have to come up with something else to take down Trump.

BEVAN: Were we talking about --

BARTIROMO: It's not going to be the economy.

BEVAN: Yes. We were talking about how the Democrats are going to counter. That's a big number they're have to contend with.

DEANGELIS: Markets will -- Markets will like it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And if --so 8.6 percent in terms of I.P. spending. Jackie DeAngelis, Jack Brewer, Tom Bevan, great to see you, everybody. Have a great weekend, everybody. "VARNEY & CO." begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: I'm seizing the day for you, Maria.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WXT-WJ11-JBHT-D3S5-00000-00ExxonMobil Share Fall Premarket After Profit Misses Estimates; Joe Biden Joins 2020 Democratic Presidential Race; Pain at the Pump; Gas Prices Soaring in California' Battle at the Border2019-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:46ZLexisNexisExxonMobil Share Fall Premarket After Profit Misses Estimates; Joe Biden Joins 2020 Democratic Presidential Race; Pain at the Pump; Gas Prices Soaring in California' Battle at the BorderLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, April 26. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. We're watching earnings. ExxonMobil just hitting the tape right now. Two Dow components in fact reporting this hour. Oil giant, ExxonMobil is hitting the tape right now with $63.63 billion dollars in revenue.

Chevron is coming out later this hour. As you can see, both stocks are fractionally better on the session. ExxonMobil pretty much flat. Chevron up two-thirds of a percent ahead of this. ExxonMobil shares are trading down right now as we are looking at some disappointment on these numbers as they just right now hit the tape. Revenue is $63.63 billion. We want to find out what the company is saying about the road ahead.

The stock has now traded lower, going into these numbers as the numbers are hitting the tape, and as you can see, we are showing you revenue is light versus the estimate which was $64.8 billion in revenue. And the actual numbers are 63.6 billion. So we got a slight miss on revenue for ExxonMobil. That's a Dow component that's going to impact markets this morning. The stock down 1-1/2 percent.

We are also waiting on GDP. This is the first reading of the first quarter. The estimate there is growth of two percent although there is a lot higher numbers on the street. J.P. Morgan is looking for 2.9 percent in GDP. Others are around 2.3 percent but the estimates that we've got for GDP for the first quarter is two percent even. Those numbers out in 30 minutes time. As you can see, futures are lower this morning.

Dow futures indicating a decline of 75 points right out of the gate, about a quarter of a percent lower. Exxon is going to be an issue here. S&P 500 down five points down five points right now and the NASDAQ down almost a point, fractional move. Intel is set to cut 28 points off the Dow Industrials at the opening of trading. So Intel is also an issue when you look at Intel and ExxonMobil looks like we're going to have a down opening this morning.

Yesterday markets were pretty active. And take a look what happened at the close. DowIndustrials were down 135 points at the close yesterday. As you can see, one-half of one percent. S&P 500 down one point, the NASDAQ was up -- the NASDAQ was up 16 points at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday.

European indices right now looking like this and they are mostly lower. FT-100 down20 points, CAC quarante in Paris is down one point and the DAX Index also slipping its negative territory right now down about a point as you can see. And in Asia overnight, the markets there were focused on the Japanese industrial production. It was down at the fastest pace in almost four years. The Nikkei Average down a quarter of a percent.

The Shanghai Composite was down 1-1/4 percent. Xi Jinping made some comments that it is willing to make some real concessions to the United States including protecting I.P. The President of China made some important comments overnight about the Chinese economy and what they're going to do. We've got all of those comments coming up. And then there's this. The Uber IPO offering 180 million shares.

The company says it will price between $44 and $50 a share. The company will start its road show today. Border crisis. At least 1300 immigrants staged a mass escape from a Mexican shelter. What the Pentagon is looking to do about the growing problem of people crossing the border into the United States. And then there's this. 2020 race, we're covering this morning. Former Vice President Joe Biden said he asked former President Obama not to endorse him.

Yes. He did not want the endorsement. President Trump says, Sleepy Joe will not be able to do the job. He calls him not the brightest light bulb in the group. The President has started the attacks on what could did his competitor come next year's election, Joe Biden. Breaking news right now. Exxon is reporting its first quarter earnings. We told you the numbers and it is a revenue missed Lauren Simonetti with more on the Exxon quarter. Lauren, over to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Yes. And Exxon, Maria, as you know is one of the two Dow stocks that our energy components reporting today at -- with the two, three percent decline in the stock to three percent decline that we're seeing right now. This is set to shave about 13 points from the Dow Jones Industrial average. But just so you know, if you add Exxon and Chevron together, this is just about five percent price weighting.

Let's get to these Exxon numbers because they are disappointing. If you look at the bottom line, the EPS number, we got 55 cents a share, we were looking for 69 cents and we're seeing a miss on revenue as well. It came in a $63.63 billion. The street was looking for 64.82. If you look deeper into this report, there is also a slight miss on the amount of oil that Exxon was hoping to pump per day.

They were looking at a number of four million barrels per day. That came in slightly below that at 3.98 million. Look ahead to this conference call. It's rare but we will once again hear from the CEO Darren Woods on that call. The focus on Wall Street we heard a few days ago that deeper into this report, there is also a slight miss on the amount of oil that Exxon was upping their dividend to 87 cents.

That was about a six percent increase. Wall Street and analyst want to see more share buybacks, increasing of dividends and basically to get the debt down for these oil giants, Exxon being one of them. So, unfortunately this looks like loser today. It's coming back a little bit. The stock right now but still down well over two percent, Maria. Chevron is coming out in about a half hour time.

Let me just get you the preview for that company. We're looking for $1.30 per share in earnings. Revenue of $38.42 billion. And of course with the Chevron story, we want to hear any and everything and if there will be a bidding war with Occidental who has a higher bid for Anadarko at this point. So, that stock ahead of the earnings for Chevron is down just about half of one percent. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren. Thanks so much. The stock of Exxon, one of the issues for the Dow certainly day down almost three percent. We are waiting on GDP. We want lock the at Trump economy right now. President Trump touted tax cuts and economic accomplishments in an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have the biggest tax cut in the history of our country. We have gotten rid of the individual mandate. We had the biggest cut in regulations which is one of the things creating all great jobs because we have the best unemployment numbers we've ever had. Today we have most people working literally today just came out we have the most people working, than we've ever had in the history of our country almost 160 million people are working to have jobs.

And it is incredible the economy is setting records. When foreign leaders come in to see me, Sean, they always say, thank you and it's great to meet you, sir, and congratulations on your economy. It's the greatest economy anywhere in the world which it is, nobody is even close to us. And that's because of the things we've done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This as we are waiting on the first quarter GDP this morning. It is due out in about 25 minutes. Joining me right now is Harvard economics professor, former IMF Chief Economist, Ken Rogoff. Ken, it is always good to see you.

KEN ROGOFF, HARVARD ECONOMICS PROFSSOR: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. How would you characterize the economy right now?

ROGOFF: It is very strong. I mean, the U.S. economy is on oasis of strength outside of China anywhere in the world, it's doing very well. I mean, it's not growing at six percent, but we're probably growing at 2-1/2 percent and I think it is possible we could be growing at three percent in coming years.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, we're getting the GDP out for the first quarter. We had a government shutdown, we had worries about Europe, worries about China in the first quarter. What would you say about things slowing down as a result of some of the outside forces that the U.S. is facing like Europe?

ROGOFF: Well, it hasn't happened. I think we talked about that when I came on last and we were wondering, you know, you were wondering if it would come here but it hasn't. Europe has picked up a little China, it's definitely stabilized but it hasn't hit us. Now, you can't read that much into one quarter's numbers and stuff like inventory accumulation. People might over rushed imports ahead of something, there goes the shutdown.

I don't know what it's going to be. I'd say between two and 2-1/2. But it isn't anything like some of the predictions that we were hearing a month ago.

BARTIROMO: It can, everybody's hair was on fire six months, recession is coming and we just keep getting one number better than the next every day.

ROGOFF: Yes. The global economy is stable. I think even compared to a couple weeks ago when I was at the IMF meetings, the global economy is looking more stable. I mean, China is a declining trend. Europe may look like Japan over the next 10 or 20 years. But the United States seems to be rising above that.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let me ask you about the op-ed that you wrote. You wrote an op-ed this morning on big tech going into 2020 and the presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, her plan to reign big tech. Your write this, Warren is courageous because big tech is big money for most leading Democratic candidates. Particularly progressives for whom California is a variable campaign financing ATM.

And although one can certainly object, Warren is not alone in thinking that tech giants have gained excessive market dominance. In fact it is one of the few issue in Washington on which there is some semblance of agreement and you're right because you got Elizabeth Warren and Ted Cruz both saying two different sides of the spectrum, both saying, get these companies to break up.

ROGOFF: Well, I don't know what the solution is but it isn't just big tech, it's big everything.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good point.

ROGOFF: Big pharma. The rise in monopoly power or something that's really started to sees economist a little last couple years. The Fed had its Jackson Hole big central bankers conference about that last year. The antitrust has been asleep the last 40 years. Forget about the last years. And big tech is kind of the poster child of this but they're not the only one.

BARTIROMO: But you know what, it's not just bigness for the tech companies. I mean, they've actually abused their power. When you take a look at how they've given, you know, all the privacy breaches, just given our data away, selling it to the advertising industry. So, do you think we're going to see a heavier hand in terms of regulation? You know what Europe has done. I don't think the U.S. is going to see -- do what Europe has done.

They're really come down hard on these companies but will we see some tweaking in terms of the regulatory burdens?

ROGOFF: Oh, absolutely. I have heard this phrase surveillance capitalism that we've moved into. I think as people understand when you write, you know, an e-mail, if you may see an advertisement about it later. If you do it on your Gmail, I mean, there are concerns like that that are coming out. But the idea that some of the big tech companies would be able to buy up potential competitors I think is very problematic and they haven't been cautious on that.

BARTIROMO: So, I -- you know, it's interesting because you know, we know this is coming, it's got to come, right? And yet, these stocks are trading at incredible valuations. So, I wonder what they think.

ROGOFF: So, one thing is that the United States is just ruling in tech. I was recently in China and you think about, oh, the China is going to take over. Well, they are competitors. I think the thing I learned more and more is Europe is not.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROGOFF: United States --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- one innovation out that's come of Europe in the last 10 years.

ROGOFF: I -- you're putting me on the spot --

(CROSSTALK)

ROGOFF: The research was probably done in the United States. I mean, they have a lot of patents but then you find out the research teams are here in the United States. So the U.S. is really leading the world in a lot of things and that I think is one of our sources of strength.

BARTIROMO: But there is worry that China is ahead of us on A.I.?

ROGOFF: They are. And it was interesting President Xi made some concessions about trade and all things they would do but I didn't hear anything about cyberspying or cybersecurity. I don't -- I don't think they will invent anything in A.I. that we didn't invent first and they steal it.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll see. And by the way, President Xi Jinping on the tape this morning with comments he made yesterday that they're going to start protecting intellectual property. They're going to buy more and they're going to -- from the U.S. and they're going to open up their markets. So, obviously the President's, you know, pushing back on China is moving the needle in terms of what the Chinese are willing to do.

ROGOFF: This was remarkable because, you know, everyone said the Chinese, they will move but they will not move because the U.S. is complaining. You let us do it if you push us, we won't do anything. And, you know, he didn't mention cyberspying but he talked about intellectual property. They event went to a currency agreement which I frankly don't think is a good idea. I think it's a bad concession but even to that, it was -- yes, really quite remarkable.

BARTIROMO: Remarkable what Xi Jinping said last night, right?

ROGOFF: Yes. Absolutely, absolutely. I mean, I don't know if he will do what he said he is going to do but that's --

BARTIROMO: That's the thing. That's why they're fighting over an enforcement mechanism.

ROGOFF: Well, that is not going to happen in a good way. But the fact he said it is already really surprising.

BARTIROMO: I totally agree. Now, you made comments recently on the Federal Reserve suggesting that the world may be facing an end to central bank independence. What do you think?

ROGOFF: Well, I mean, certainly you look around at smaller countries, you know, Turkey, Hungary, Venezuela, Argentina, there have been a lot of problems with central bank independents. But I think the fundamental problem is a lot of people, you talk to people and they say, inflation, that's 20th century. You can't have inflation in the 21st Century. Why do we need an independent central bank on? I think they've got that so wrong. Unfortunately in some countries I hope not ours will find out.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. You're to be my special guest this weekends, Ken, and I'm -- I appreciate you joining me this weekend on "MARIA BARTIROMO'S WALL STREET", THAT'S tonight AT 9:00 p.m. Eastern. Join myself and Ken Rogoff for that. We will see you little later. Thank you, Ken.

Coming up, the advance reading on first quarter GDP is due out in about 15 minutes' time. We are expecting two percent growth for the quarter. This is the first reading for the first quarter. We'll have that number when we come right back. And then earnings in focus. Disappointing results from oil giant ExxonMobil. Stock is down 2-1/3 percent right now. Back in a minute.

urn:contentItem:5YP4-3651-F146-C0PM-00000-00Eyecarrot Sports Vision Partnership with Eli Wilson Goaltending Redefines How 50,000 Aspiring Goalies See the Game2020-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:46ZLexisNexisEyecarrot Sports Vision Partnership with Eli Wilson Goaltending Redefines How 50,000 Aspiring Goalies See the Game

(via TheNewswire)

Toronto, New York - TheNewswire - April 17th, 2020 - Eyecarrot Innovations Corp., (Eyecarrot) (TSXV:EYC) | (OTC:EYCCF) | (2EYA:GR) is excited to announce a multi-year partnership with Eli Wilson Goaltending, a world leader in goaltending development, goaltending camps, and clinics. Eli Wilson has established himself as one of the premier goaltending coaches in the world through his work with dozens of goaltenders in the National Hockey League (NHL) and Team Canada. The partnership will provide Eli Wilson Goaltending camps with the Binovi Touch neurovision sports training hardware, alongside screen-based resources for athletes to support their development on and off the ice. The Eli Wilson Goaltending partnership will ultimately expose 600 active goaltending camp participants, aged 10 to 19 years and a global network of over 50,000 aspiring goaltending athletes to Eyecarrot's Binovi Sport Vision Platform for off-ice training. As many nations continue to practice social distancing during COVID-19 and post pandemic, the Binovi Sports Vision Platform offers accessible turnkey athletic resources in step with subscription-based home fitness solutions Tonal, Peloton (PTON: NASDAQ) and Mirror. A subscription structure will support the company's global product scaling strategy and "at-home" consumer offerings.

"I emphatically believe the best way to develop goaltenders is by teaching a system within a system. Quality drills, attention to detail, repetition and simplicity are major factors in building successful goaltenders. The goaltender must learn needed skills in a progressive manner in a controlled environment. With Binovi, we are gaining a sports vision training system to improve vision in that same controlled way, ensuring proper analysis and progress," commented Eli Wilson, Eli Wilson Goaltending Founder, CEO

Under his tutelage, Eli's camps --which see over 600 athletes annually-- have produced more than 50 NHL draft picks, over 60 Division I, Canadian University goaltenders, and more than 200 players drafted by Major Junior teams. His goaltenders have gone on to win numerous prestigious awards and championships, including the Stanley Cup, Conn Smythe Trophy, Vezina Trophy, World Junior Gold Medals, American Hockey League (AHL) championships, AHL Playoff MVPs, Western Hockey League (WHL) Goaltender of the Year awards, Ontario Hockey League (OHL) Goaltender of the Year awards, and Canadian Hockey League (CHL) Goaltender of the Year awards. In addition to standard camp programming, Eli has introduced a number of specialty camps, including the popular 24/7 camp, where goaltenders actually live and train with Eli over a three-day weekend. A main staple of Eli's year-round training is advanced video technology, whereby he and his staff can analyze video remotely to further goaltending development.

This strategic partnership will support Eyecarrot's aggressive positioning of its sports vision performance offerings in the sport of hockey through an increased presence in key hockey development programs including direct NHL team alignments. Hockey, a leading sport in Canada, will benefit from big-tech partnerships of this nature that are designed to enhance athlete performance at all development levels of the sport.

"We're very excited to be working with an athletic training team that clearly has a very high drive for success, and such an incredible track record for turning out exceptional players. Our goal is to see Binovi boost the performance of athletes going through these camps and training regimens. After all, competition is what drives sport, and any edge players and their training teams can get to get that competitive edge over an opponent is key. We look forward to working alongside Eli and his team as we continue to develop Binovi for sports," stated Adam Cegielski, President and CEO.

Click here for more information on Binovi Sports Vision Training.

About Eli Wilson Goaltending

Eli Wilson has worked with over 30 NHL goalies (and counting) to sharpen all essential goaltending skills, including mental conditioning and off-ice training. Eli's programs help to hone an athlete's reflexes and improve agility in the net. The camp experience mirrors how Pro and NHL goaltenders' practice, train, think, and act, to get to the top of their game. In 2004, Eli was named to Hockey Canada's goaltending consultant group. He has consulted with Creative Artists Agency (CAA) Sports during their summer development camps for top young prospects in Los Angeles, California. Eli has also traveled to South Korea to work with the Kangwon Land Ice Hockey team and other young goaltenders in the country. From 2007 through 2010, Eli was the goaltending coach for the Ottawa Senators, where he was responsible for the Ottawa Senators goaltenders as well as for the goalies playing for their AHL affiliate, the Binghamton Senators. Established in 2010, the Eli Wilson Goaltending program sees over 600 athletes every year and helps give them the competitive edge to set themselves apart in a very challenging and exclusive club.

About the NHL

The National Hockey League (NHL(R)), founded in 1917, consists of 31 Member Clubs, each reflecting the League's international makeup with players from more than 20 countries represented on team rosters, vying for the most cherished and historic trophy in professional sports - the Stanley Cup(R). Every year, the NHL entertains more than 670 million fans in-arena and through its partners on national television and radio; more than 151 million followers - league, team and player accounts combined - across Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat and YouTube; and more than 100 million fans online at NHL.com. The League broadcasts games in more than 160 countries and territories through its rightsholders including NBC/NBCSN and the NHL Network(TM) in the U.S., Sportsnet and TVA in Canada, Viasat in the Nordic Region and CCTV and Tencent in China. The NHL reaches fans worldwide with games available online in every country including via its live and on-demand streaming service NHL.TV(TM). Fans are engaged across the League's digital assets on mobile devices via the free NHL(R) App; across nine social media platforms; on SiriusXM NHL Network Radio(TM); and on NHL.com, available in eight languages and featuring unprecedented access to player and team statistics as well as every regular-season and playoff game box score dating back to the League's inception, powered by SAP. The NHL is committed to building healthy and vibrant communities through the sport of hockey by increasing youth participation and engagement; fostering positive family experiences; promoting inclusion, positive culture and leadership; and supporting sustainable community impact.

About Eyecarrot Innovations Corp

Eyecarrot is a human performance technology company that has developed Binovi, a hardware and software-centered platform. Binovi combines hardware, software, specialized expert knowledge, and unique big data insights in order to deliver customized one-on-one training and treatment. Binovi is designed for vision optimization and the enhancement of cognitive skills related to human performance. We are working together under a common banner to help neuro-optometry, vision rehabilitation, and vision performance professionals gain measurable results in less time, and with less effort.

Adam Cegielski

President | CEO

Tania Archer

Head of Global Marketing | Sales | Strategic Partnerships

Investor Relations

Email: invest@eyecarrot.com

Toll-free: 1 (844) 866-6162

https://www.eyecarrot.com/investors/

urn:contentItem:5YP4-38C1-JDN4-N51R-00000-00Eyecarrot Sports Vision Partnership with Eli Wilson Goaltending Redefines How 50,000 Aspiring Goalies See the Game2020-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:46ZLexisNexisEyecarrot Sports Vision Partnership with Eli Wilson Goaltending Redefines How 50,000 Aspiring Goalies See the Game

(via TheNewswire)

Toronto, New York - TheNewswire - April 17th, 2020 - Eyecarrot Innovations Corp., (Eyecarrot) (TSXV:EYC) | (OTC:EYCCF) | (2EYA:GR) is excited to announce a multi-year partnership with Eli Wilson Goaltending, a world leader in goaltending development, goaltending camps, and clinics. Eli Wilson has established himself as one of the premier goaltending coaches in the world through his work with dozens of goaltenders in the National Hockey League (NHL) and Team Canada. The partnership will provide Eli Wilson Goaltending camps with the Binovi Touch neurovision sports training hardware, alongside screen-based resources for athletes to support their development on and off the ice. The Eli Wilson Goaltending partnership will ultimately expose 600 active goaltending camp participants, aged 10 to 19 years and a global network of over 50,000 aspiring goaltending athletes to Eyecarrot's Binovi Sport Vision Platform for off-ice training. As many nations continue to practice social distancing during COVID-19 and post pandemic, the Binovi Sports Vision Platform offers accessible turnkey athletic resources in step with subscription-based home fitness solutions Tonal, Peloton (PTON: NASDAQ) and Mirror. A subscription structure will support the company's global product scaling strategy and "at-home" consumer offerings.

"I emphatically believe the best way to develop goaltenders is by teaching a system within a system. Quality drills, attention to detail, repetition and simplicity are major factors in building successful goaltenders. The goaltender must learn needed skills in a progressive manner in a controlled environment. With Binovi, we are gaining a sports vision training system to improve vision in that same controlled way, ensuring proper analysis and progress," commented Eli Wilson, Eli Wilson Goaltending Founder, CEO

Under his tutelage, Eli's camps --which see over 600 athletes annually-- have produced more than 50 NHL draft picks, over 60 Division I, Canadian University goaltenders, and more than 200 players drafted by Major Junior teams. His goaltenders have gone on to win numerous prestigious awards and championships, including the Stanley Cup, Conn Smythe Trophy, Vezina Trophy, World Junior Gold Medals, American Hockey League (AHL) championships, AHL Playoff MVPs, Western Hockey League (WHL) Goaltender of the Year awards, Ontario Hockey League (OHL) Goaltender of the Year awards, and Canadian Hockey League (CHL) Goaltender of the Year awards. In addition to standard camp programming, Eli has introduced a number of specialty camps, including the popular 24/7 camp, where goaltenders actually live and train with Eli over a three-day weekend. A main staple of Eli's year-round training is advanced video technology, whereby he and his staff can analyze video remotely to further goaltending development.

This strategic partnership will support Eyecarrot's aggressive positioning of its sports vision performance offerings in the sport of hockey through an increased presence in key hockey development programs including direct NHL team alignments. Hockey, a leading sport in Canada, will benefit from big-tech partnerships of this nature that are designed to enhance athlete performance at all development levels of the sport.

"We're very excited to be working with an athletic training team that clearly has a very high drive for success, and such an incredible track record for turning out exceptional players. Our goal is to see Binovi boost the performance of athletes going through these camps and training regimens. After all, competition is what drives sport, and any edge players and their training teams can get to get that competitive edge over an opponent is key. We look forward to working alongside Eli and his team as we continue to develop Binovi for sports," stated Adam Cegielski, President and CEO.

Click here for more information on Binovi Sports Vision Training.

About Eli Wilson Goaltending

Eli Wilson has worked with over 30 NHL goalies (and counting) to sharpen all essential goaltending skills, including mental conditioning and off-ice training. Eli's programs help to hone an athlete's reflexes and improve agility in the net. The camp experience mirrors how Pro and NHL goaltenders' practice, train, think, and act, to get to the top of their game. In 2004, Eli was named to Hockey Canada's goaltending consultant group. He has consulted with Creative Artists Agency (CAA) Sports during their summer development camps for top young prospects in Los Angeles, California. Eli has also traveled to South Korea to work with the Kangwon Land Ice Hockey team and other young goaltenders in the country. From 2007 through 2010, Eli was the goaltending coach for the Ottawa Senators, where he was responsible for the Ottawa Senators goaltenders as well as for the goalies playing for their AHL affiliate, the Binghamton Senators. Established in 2010, the Eli Wilson Goaltending program sees over 600 athletes every year and helps give them the competitive edge to set themselves apart in a very challenging and exclusive club.

About the NHL

The National Hockey League (NHL(R)), founded in 1917, consists of 31 Member Clubs, each reflecting the League's international makeup with players from more than 20 countries represented on team rosters, vying for the most cherished and historic trophy in professional sports - the Stanley Cup(R). Every year, the NHL entertains more than 670 million fans in-arena and through its partners on national television and radio; more than 151 million followers - league, team and player accounts combined - across Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat and YouTube; and more than 100 million fans online at NHL.com. The League broadcasts games in more than 160 countries and territories through its rightsholders including NBC/NBCSN and the NHL Network(TM) in the U.S., Sportsnet and TVA in Canada, Viasat in the Nordic Region and CCTV and Tencent in China. The NHL reaches fans worldwide with games available online in every country including via its live and on-demand streaming service NHL.TV(TM). Fans are engaged across the League's digital assets on mobile devices via the free NHL(R) App; across nine social media platforms; on SiriusXM NHL Network Radio(TM); and on NHL.com, available in eight languages and featuring unprecedented access to player and team statistics as well as every regular-season and playoff game box score dating back to the League's inception, powered by SAP. The NHL is committed to building healthy and vibrant communities through the sport of hockey by increasing youth participation and engagement; fostering positive family experiences; promoting inclusion, positive culture and leadership; and supporting sustainable community impact.

About Eyecarrot Innovations Corp

Eyecarrot is a human performance technology company that has developed Binovi, a hardware and software-centered platform. Binovi combines hardware, software, specialized expert knowledge, and unique big data insights in order to deliver customized one-on-one training and treatment. Binovi is designed for vision optimization and the enhancement of cognitive skills related to human performance. We are working together under a common banner to help neuro-optometry, vision rehabilitation, and vision performance professionals gain measurable results in less time, and with less effort.

Adam Cegielski

President | CEO

Tania Archer

Head of Global Marketing | Sales | Strategic Partnerships

Investor Relations
